not_covered.title: Not Covered by Insurance
not_covered.summary: Your policy does not cover windshield damage.
not_covered.explanation: Why You're Not Covered: • Windshield damage requires comprehensive coverage • Liability-only policies never cover your own vehicle damage • Collision coverage only applies if damage occurred in an accident • Consider adding comprehensive coverage to prevent this in the future Your Options: • Pay out of pocket: Repairs cost $50-$150, replacements $200-$1,000+ • Upgrade your policy: Add comprehensive coverage for future incidents • Check for exceptions: Some states or policies have special glass provisions
nextSteps: Check if repair is cheaper than replacement

fully_covered.title: $0 Out of Pocket!
fully_covered.summary: Your insurance will cover 100% of the cost.
fully_covered.explanation: Great News! ✓ Your insurance will cover 100% of the cost ✓ No deductible applies to this claim ✓ Most glass claims don't affect your premium ✓ Contact your insurer or go to an approved shop to begin the claim Filing Your Claim - Next Steps: 1. Document damage with clear photos from multiple angles 2. Contact your insurer to file a claim and get a claim number 3. Choose your shop - you have the legal right to select any installer 4. Don't accept pressure to use aftermarket glass if you have ADAS 5. Confirm calibration is included in the approved work 6. Pay only your deductible to the shop (if applicable) 7. Get documentation including warranty and calibration reports

partially_covered.title: Partially Covered
partially_covered.summary: Your insurance covers this, but you'll owe your deductible.
partially_covered.explanation: If you have comprehensive coverage, your windshield replacement should be covered. However, you will likely need to pay your comprehensive deductible first. Deductible Considerations: • Low deductible ($0-$100): Claim makes sense • Medium deductible ($250-$500): Compare to out-of-pocket cost • High deductible ($500+): May be cheaper to pay yourself Rate Impact: Some insurers may raise your rates for a comprehensive claim. Ask before filing. Critical Safety Considerations: • OEM vs Aftermarket Glass: Insurance may default to cheaper aftermarket glass, which can have optical distortions that interfere with ADAS camera systems • ADAS Calibration: Modern vehicles require mandatory camera recalibration after windshield replacement. Ensure this cost ($75-$300+) is included in the quote • Quality Matters: If you don't have OEM coverage, you may need to pay the difference for manufacturer-original glass to ensure proper ADAS function

check_policy.title: Check Your Policy
check_policy.summary: You may have coverage, but need to verify with your insurer.
check_policy.explanation: Based on your answers, you may have glass coverage, but the details are unclear. The best step is to call your insurance company directly and ask: Key Questions to Ask: • "Do I have comprehensive coverage?" • "Does my policy cover glass damage?" • "What is my glass or comprehensive deductible?" • "Will a glass claim increase my rates?" • "Do you have a preferred shop network?" • "Do I have OEM parts coverage for glass?" • "Is ADAS calibration covered in the replacement cost?"
